Watch what happens as these plants move through their biome over time.  They do not try to outcompete other plants, or else they would be a monoculture.  In truth they clear up nickel, binding it up so other plants come in and take their place.  Any area that has too much near the surface becomes a major growth area for these, and the cycle continues.  The goal isn't plant-victory but sustainability of life no matter what the local soil content is.  Glance at your lawn and notice how dandelions only grow on compacted, calcium deficient soil where grass can't yet.  So, the large roots break up and aerate the soil while bringing up calcium from deeper down when they die.  All plants serve many, many roles in maintaining ecosystems.

Nickel is the German and Netherlands Dutch word for "devil." Pumpernickel bread means "devil's fart" bread.
"Mafic" refers to any rock high in iron, nickel and/or manganese. The word is actually a combination  of the chemical symbols for manganese (Ma) and Iron (Fe) plus an -ic suffix.

Plant-based industry... hmm, let's see:

The ideal basis would be a new genus of trees whose sap can be harvested in the same fashion as maple and rubber trees that grow relatively fast and produce a decent amount of metal-rich sap; with the added benefits of both dealing with soil and air pollution.
However, there are several hurdles that need to be overcome before they become a functional, integral part of the world:


1. Growth rate: Rubber trees reach full height in around 13 years, while maples takes between 20 to 30 years. The ideal growth of these hypothetical man-made genus of trees should then take between 12 to 15 years, if one is to use the rubber tree as basis for the breeds.


2. Yields: Continuing with the rubber tree example, it is a matter of how soon and for how long can they produce their sap. Tapping (the procedure to extract the sap) for rubber trees begins when they are around 6 years old, and can be tapped for up to approximately 26 years. One tree can produce 19 pounds (roughly 8.5 kg) of rubber annually. Therefore, a viable hyperaccumulator tree intended for metal recovery should aim for a similar range of yields per yer per life cycle.


3. Toxicity: Bearing what she mentioned about allelopathy (2:39), trees that thrive in metal-rich soils can be harmful to other flora and fauna, even if they haven't specifically evolved to be so TO THEM. While it is true that these trees in THEIR OWN NATIVE ENVIRONMENT are perfectly integrated into the ecosystem, we must not forget the issues caused by other aggressive trees that have inflicted environmental damage when introduced into other ecosystems (the eucalyptus issues, specifically). Trees are natural havens and food supplies for a huge variety of life forms, and the kind of impact that Hyperaccumulator trees can theoretically produce could be massive if done wrong. And this is to say nothing of the potential environmental problems of the sap extraction alone (rubber tapping residues can affect soil and water). This takes us then to


4. Infrastructure: Considering all this, specific infrastructure to support both the trees and the surrounding environment is capital. The example of the rubber tree is a good frame of reference, encompassing both the potential environmental hazards and industry-related issues (rubber trees compete with oil palms). Care has to be taken not too create invasive monocultures (like in the case of oil palms); therefore, the hyperaccumulators must have around themselves a proper ecosystem that acts as a buffer between them and the environment. This translates in the actual engineering of the soil itself where they are to be grown, with previous preparation to avoid including components that could kill the hyperaccumulators themselves, or the other plants/animals that share their environment (hypothetically, a nickel tree may not survive if their soil has other trace metals it cannot handle). Traditional plantation approach therefore, is not a viable approach, regardless of higher short-term yields. New method are required to make it both ecologically and economically viable. However, even if those issues are tackled, there remains a rather large and potentially game changing issue that needs to be considered, namely


5. Large-scale, long-term impact: As the palm oil industry so glaringly demonstrates, large scale commercial agriculture RESHAPES BOTH THE ENVIRONMENT AND THE SOCIETIES AROUND THEM. The first effect, the environment impact does not only include short-term environmental destruction and purging of other lifeforms (which in themselves are long-term, butterfly effects); they contribute to the birth of unexpected plagues, ranging from flora, fauna, fungi, insects, bacteria, and maybe even viruses (who know? Maybe the Virus-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named came from that source) as nature struggles to fix itself, eventually pushing evolution in directions we cannot fathom (ok, I got a bit overboard there, but still, food for thought). Then, the social issues... as monoculture plants themselves are aggressively invasive, so is the culture surrounding them. Monoculture agriculture affects local agriculture culture practices (such an ironical level of meta-redundant tongue twister). One of the chief issues is that, due to its higher revenue, farmers opt for abandoning the production of other plants, which in turn affects the locally produced food supply of their communities, which makes necessary for food to be brought from outside, which creates inflation, which makes people seek more reliable sources of income, which may in the end turn them back to palm oil production, feeding the cycle. And this is nothing to say that the conjoined issues created by land appropriation (legal or otherwise), which creates the classic human disputes that are such a seedbed for strife.


And these are merely the mayor, easy-to-pop-off-your-head issues... who knows how many things are necessary before Plant-based industry can become a proper, sustainable part of our Sid Meier's-style civilization (a perfect simulator to illustrate my points on the issue of 'invasiveness'). Truly, this weird, ENDANGERED trees poke at the roots (pun intended) of so many of our current world problems. If we are seriously considering adding hyperaccumultors to our arsenal of world-changing crops (and we ARE doing it already), then I think it is time to REALLY sit down and truly see the big picture. Our social ecosystem is as unbalanced as the artificial ecosystems we have created through industrial-scale agriculture. Like I said above, in a not-so-jokingly fashion, this hits the roots of our problems, including, but not limited to:


-Our reckless search for short-term gain

-Our irresponsible approach to the environment and our own culture
-The basic, underlying flaws and limitations of our modern society when confronted with systems with such high order of complexity as the ecosystem of THE PLANET WHERE WE LIVE
-The untenable situation of the modern society that still refuses to address these issues


And many, many more human-born problems...


What are our solutions? For yes, even something as this can be fixed... if we set our minds to it.
How about eco-social community designs? If we can make a balanced garden by adding plants that complement and help each other survive, can we integrate industries that co-exist in a balanced fashion, filling the niches in-between?
How about reevaluating and restructuring our commercial markets and industries? So much is wasted that could be used/applied to other areas, from resources to techniques. Synergy is a practice that yields good economical results, imagine what would happen if that model of thought could be applied to these issues.
And what about governments? Policies, when applied properly, can boost both the society and the economy, and be fair to the individual.
But, what about our own ideologies that fuel the issues and choke the solutions? Our approach to all the issues is sadly narrow and one-track minded, but if we realize that we can fix our environment, our societies, our ideologies, AND STILL PROFIT FROM IT (renewable energy's emerging market, anyone?), then yes


These trees truly represent the seed of a new future.

Speaking of metals, molybdenum is one of those rarely spoken-about metals and it has an atomic number of 42, it's actually essential for many living organisms including humans. Molybdenum enzymes in humans have a few purposes, among them they help us break down the toxic byproducts from the metabolic breakdown of proteins.

The vernacular name in French is "Sève Bleue, Arbre à Nickel". In English it's "Blue Sap, Nickel Tree" neither are that METAL of Tree Names. However if we translate it into Swedish we get "Blå Sap, Nickelträd" and we have METAL!

Seems to me it just evolved as chance.  A mutation allowed minimal ability to survive at the edge of such a deposit.. the plant grew and it's seeds continued to grow there when others did not.  Some of these seeds may have changed through further mutation to adapt more firmly to be able to survive in that environment.. so those seeds became dominant in the area and were able to outlive their less-adapted predecessors.  Repeat this cycle for hundreds or thousands or more years and this is the result.  A tree perfectly adapted to the conditions in which it now thrives.  Maybe this can be used for other metals?  Maybe not 'this' tree but a similar concept with shorter-lived plants that could be used to adapt similar strategies through successive generational adaptations?   We see it is possible so that means it might be able to be accomplished for other purposes as well.

I used to be a cool guy. Then I tired dating this cute science nerd in college. She wasn’t my type at all. I went for the valley girls. Anyway....She wouldn’t give me the time of day. So I kept taking more and more science classes. After a while, I forgot all about that girl I was chasing because I found out a lot of cute girls love science. There was a deli of fine female science lovers at my college and I wanted to be the wheat bread to the sandwich.

I looked up one day and I had BA in Natural Science. After some soul searching I thought about my 1st crush. She was my 6th science teacher. So I decided to be a science teacher. Now I hope I can be that special teacher that inspires my students to find a love for science.
